required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 13, 2016
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Clinical Study of the Mirabilis High-Intensity Focused Ultrasound System for Non-Invasive Treatment of Uterine Fibroids
clinical_study.official_title: Clinical Study of a Focused Ultrasound Device for Treating Uterine Fibroids and Menorrhagia

oversight_info.authority: Mexico: Federal Commission for Protection Against Health Risks

brief_summary.textblock: The Mirabilis High-Intensity Focused Ultrasound (HIFU) Treatment System delivers therapeutic focused ultrasound energy to the uterus under integrated ultrasound imaging guidance to offer non-invasive treatment for uterine fibroids. The purpose of this clinical study is to assess the initial safety and performance of the Mirabilis HIFU Treatment System for transabdominal treatment of uterine fibroids in eligible women who are scheduled to undergo hysterectomy following treatment with the device or who are seeking relief from fibroid-related symptoms.

clinical_study.study_design: Intervention Model: Single Group Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Treatment

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluation of All Adverse Events Encountered
primary_outcome.time_frame: Adverse Events were monitored until the patient's exit from the study (up to 6 months post-treatment).
primary_outcome.description: Safety of the treatment was determined by evaluating the incidence of Adverse Events and Adverse Device Effects. Adverse Device Effects are Adverse Events that are related to treatment with the device. Relatedness of an Adverse Event to the treatment was determined on a case-by-case basis by the investigator. The average number of Serious Adverse Device Effects per patient and the average number of Non-Serious Adverse Device Effects per patient are reported to provide numeric outcomes of this evaluation.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: The NPV was measured between 0 and 7 days post-treatment.
secondary_outcome.description: Efficacy of the treatment was quantified by measuring the HIFU-related Non-Perfused Volume (NPV) of tissue in each patient using either post-treatment contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or pathology assessment following hysterectomy. The NPV is used to measure the amount of tissue that was treated during the procedure.

arm_group.description: Patients in this arm will receive fibroid treatment using the Mirabilis High-Intensity Focused Ultrasound Treatment System.

intervention.intervention_name: Mirabilis High-Intensity Focused Ultrasound Treatment System
intervention.description: The intervention consists of a treatment session with the device, during which focused ultrasound energy is applied across the intact abdominal wall to ablate appropriately selected uterine fibroids under ultrasound imaging guidance.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Female
- Age 18-55 years
- Patients seeking relief from uterine fibroid related symptoms, including those scheduled to undergo abdominal hysterectomy due to benign pathology
- Patients able and willing to provide informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Visible scar within the HIFU beam path that cannot be avoided
- Known or suspected abdominal adhesions between the anterior uterine serosa and the abdominal wall
- Currently pregnant or desire to become pregnant in the future
- Pelvic malignancy
- Pelvic congenital malformation
- Acute pelvic infection
- Otherwise determined by a physician to be inappropriate for the study

facility.name: Hospital Universitario, Universidad Autonoma de Nuevo Leon

results_reference.citation: Garza Leal JG, Hernandez Leon I, Castillo Saenz L, Aguilar Aguirre JM, Islas Lagos JJ, Parsons JE, Martin PM, and Lau MPH. Refinement of the Shell Ablation Technique for Rapid In-Office Treatment of Uterine Fibroids under Ultrasound Imaging Guidance using the Mirabilis Transabdominal HIFU System. 15th International Symposium on Therapeutic Ultrasound Program and Abstracts: 156 (2015).

Garza Leal JG, Hernandez Leon I, Castillo Saenz L, Aguilar Aguirre JM, Islas Lagos JJ, Parsons JE, Darlington GP, and Lau MPH. In-Office Rapid Volumetric Ablation of Uterine Fibroids under Ultrasound Imaging Guidance: Preclinical and Early Clinical Experience with the Mirabilis Transabdominal HIFU Treatment System. 14th International Symposium on Therapeutic Ultrasound Program and Abstracts: 43 (2014).

Lau M, Aguilar Aguirre JM, Islas Lagos JJ, and Garza Leal JG. Office Based High-Speed Ultrasound Image Guided HIFU (High Intensity Focused Ultrasound) Ablation of Uterine Fibroids. Gynecol. Surg. 11 (Suppl. 1): 149-150 (2014).

participant_flow.recruitment_details: All patients underwent transabdominal uterine fibroid treatment with the Mirabilis High-Intensity Focused Ultrasound Treatment System between January 8, 2011 and November 21, 2014 at two clinical sites in Mexico. The study was completed on May 20, 2015.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Patients were screened prior to treatment for eligibility criteria including size, location, and tissue characteristics of their uterine fibroid(s). Those patients meeting the established eligibility criteria were then scheduled for treatment.

baseline.population: Baseline characteristics are reported for the entire study population (all treated patients).

outcome.description: Safety of the treatment was determined by evaluating the incidence of Adverse Events and Adverse Device Effects. Adverse Device Effects are Adverse Events that are related to treatment with the device. Relatedness of an Adverse Event to the treatment was determined on a case-by-case basis by the investigator. The average number of Serious Adverse Device Effects per patient and the average number of Non-Serious Adverse Device Effects per patient are reported to provide numeric outcomes of this evaluation.

outcome.population: All Adverse Device Effects are reported for the entire study population (all treated patients).

measure.title: Evaluation of All Adverse Events Encountered
measure.description: Safety of the treatment was determined by evaluating the incidence of Adverse Events and Adverse Device Effects. Adverse Device Effects are Adverse Events that are related to treatment with the device. Relatedness of an Adverse Event to the treatment was determined on a case-by-case basis by the investigator. The average number of Serious Adverse Device Effects per patient and the average number of Non-Serious Adverse Device Effects per patient are reported to provide numeric outcomes of this evaluation.

category.sub_title: Serious Adverse Device Effects Per Patient
Non-Serious Adverse Device Effects Per Patient

outcome.title: HIFU-related Non-Perfused Volume (NPV)
outcome.description: Efficacy of the treatment was quantified by measuring the HIFU-related Non-Perfused Volume (NPV) of tissue in each patient using either post-treatment contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or pathology assessment following hysterectomy. The NPV is used to measure the amount of tissue that was treated during the procedure.
outcome.time_frame: The NPV was measured between 0 and 7 days post-treatment.
outcome.population: HIFU-related Non-Perfused Volumes (NPVs) are reported for all treated patients in whom they were observed following treatment. NPV outcomes are stratified between two cohorts: an early Development Cohort and a final Validation Cohort.

group.title: Development Cohort With NPVs Observed
group.description: The Development Cohort includes the first 37 patients treated in the study sequence. Treatments in the Development Cohort were used for dose-ranging purposes to develop the most appropriate HIFU parameters for uterine fibroid treatment with the device. Outcomes are reported for the 33 out of 37 patients (89.2%) in the Development Cohort with NPVs observed following treatment. Overall, 68 out of 73 patients (93.2%) in the entire study had NPVs observed following treatment.

group.title: Validation Cohort With NPVs Observed
group.description: The Validation Cohort includes the last 36 patients treated in the study sequence. Treatments in the Validation Cohort were used to refine and validate the final HIFU parameters for uterine fibroid treatment with the device. Outcomes are reported for the 35 out of 36 patients (97.2%) in the Validation Cohort with NPVs observed following treatment. Overall, 68 out of 73 patients (93.2%) in the entire study had NPVs observed following treatment.

measure.title: HIFU-related Non-Perfused Volume (NPV)
measure.description: Efficacy of the treatment was quantified by measuring the HIFU-related Non-Perfused Volume (NPV) of tissue in each patient using either post-treatment contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) or pathology assessment following hysterectomy. The NPV is used to measure the amount of tissue that was treated during the procedure.

outcome.title: Total Time Required to Deliver Treatment
outcome.description: The total treatment time was measured for each patient from the beginning of HIFU energy emission until HIFU energy emission stopped.
outcome.time_frame: The total treatment time was measured on the day of treatment.
outcome.population: Total treatment times are reported for all treated patients. Total treatment times are stratified between two cohorts: an early Development Cohort and a final Validation Cohort.

group.title: Entire Development Cohort
group.description: The Development Cohort includes the first 37 patients treated in the study sequence. Treatments in the Development Cohort were used for dose-ranging purposes to develop the most appropriate HIFU parameters for uterine fibroid treatment with the device. Outcomes are reported for all 37 patients in the Development Cohort.

group.title: Entire Validation Cohort
group.description: The Validation Cohort includes the last 36 patients treated in the study sequence. Treatments in the Validation Cohort were used to refine and validate the final HIFU parameters for uterine fibroid treatment with the device. Outcomes are reported for all 36 patients in the Validation Cohort.

measure.title: Total Time Required to Deliver Treatment
measure.description: The total treatment time was measured for each patient from the beginning of HIFU energy emission until HIFU energy emission stopped.

reported_events.time_frame: Monitoring for Adverse Events occurred from January 8, 2011 until May 20, 2015. Adverse Events were monitored until each patient's exit from the study, which was up to 6 months following treatment.
reported_events.desc: All Adverse Events are reported for all patients receiving treatment, including those events not related to treatment. Adverse Events were reported spontaneously by patients, observed by the investigator or other personnel, and/or elicited during patient queries at regular follow-up intervals. Descriptions were mapped to standardized terms.

group.title: All Treated Patients
group.description: All patients who underwent treatment with the device

event.description: related to concurrent E. coli infection

event.sub_title: Depressed respiration with apnea unrelated to treatment
Nausea with vomiting unrelated to treatment

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
